articles.headline: N.F.L. Players May Have an Ally in Their Protests: Labor Law
articles.snippet: In a debate over how far workers can go in banding together without retribution by their employers, many experts say showing solidarity is a legal right.
articles.abstract: In a debate over how far workers can go in banding together without retribution by their employers, many experts say showing solidarity is a legal right.
articles.lead_paragraph: As National Football League team owners consider President Trump’s call to fire players who refuse to stand for the national anthem, they have stumbled into one of the most consequential debates in today’s workplace: How far can workers go in banding together to address problems related to their employment?

articles.headline: Tech Giants, Once Seen as Saviors, Are Now Viewed as Threats
articles.snippet: American tech companies positioned themselves as entities that brought positive change by connecting people and spreading information. Perceptions are shifting.
articles.abstract: American tech companies positioned themselves as entities that brought positive change by connecting people and spreading information. Perceptions are shifting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At the start of this decade, the Arab Spring blossomed with the help of social media. That is the sort of story the tech industry loves to tell about itself: It is bringing freedom, enlightenment and a better future for all mankind.

articles.headline: Gunshots, a Cry of ‘Kill the Hostages,’ Then Freedom for Canadian-American Family
articles.snippet: An American woman, her Canadian husband and three children were freed in a dramatic raid after being held for five years by a Taliban faction, the Haqqani network.
articles.abstract: An American woman, her Canadian husband and three children were freed in a dramatic raid after being held for five years by a Taliban faction, the Haqqani network.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stuffed by their captors into the back of a car with their children as they were being ferried across the rugged tribal areas of northwest Pakistan, an American woman and her Canadian husband were in the final moments of their five-year ordeal as hostages.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Ian Austen

articles.headline: To Court Workers, Japanese Firms Try Being More Gay-Friendly
articles.snippet: A combination of evolving social attitudes and competition for talent is forcing companies in Japan to become more welcoming to gay employees.
articles.abstract: A combination of evolving social attitudes and competition for talent is forcing companies in Japan to become more welcoming to gay employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Once a week, the Japanese insurance company where Shunsuke Nakamura works tries to enliven its morning staff meeting by having employees give personal presentations. The topics tend to be mostly innocuous: hobbies, pets or wine recommendations.

articles.headline: Trump Disavows Nuclear Deal, but Doesn’t Scrap It
articles.snippet: President Trump said he would seek Congress to define “trigger points,” that could prompt the United States to reimpose sanctions on Iran if violated.
articles.abstract: President Trump said he would seek Congress to define “trigger points,” that could prompt the United States to reimpose sanctions on Iran if violated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump announced on Friday his decision to disavow the Iran nuclear agreement, threatening to leave the deal altogether if it was not amended to permanently block Tehran from building nuclear weapons or intercontinental missiles.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: U.S. and Europe May Collide on Taxing Apple and Amazon
articles.snippet: Other countries have their eyes on the money that lawmakers want to put on American tax rolls. But a European crackdown could work in Washington’s favor.
articles.abstract: Other countries have their eyes on the money that lawmakers want to put on American tax rolls. But a European crackdown could work in Washington’s favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump and congressional lawmakers are not the only ones interested in collecting taxes on global profits that American corporations are hoarding overseas. European regulators, knee deep in a campaign to stamp out tax avoidance, have their own plans for that money.

articles.headline: This Is Not Arthur Laffer’s Famous Napkin
articles.snippet: The Smithsonian says that it has the most famous napkin in economic history. The available evidence suggests that’s probably not true.
articles.abstract: The Smithsonian says that it has the most famous napkin in economic history. The available evidence suggests that’s probably not true.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is one of the iconic moments in modern economics: A young professor named Arthur Laffer sketched a curve on a bar napkin in 1974 to show an aide to President Gerald R. Ford why the federal government should cut taxes.
